repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body: Right – editing artefact. I'll delete it.

The only thing worth considering is `bool(char_ptr[:5])` which goes though `PyBytes_FromStringAndSize` which does handle NULL. It's a pretty odd thing to do though.

I checked and it doesn't go through this optimization but I could see that accidentally changing. I wonder if it's worth a test that the index node doesn't get optimized out just so we know if we've accidentally broken this?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -14643,6 +14663,21 @@ def coerce_to_boolean(self, env):
         if (arg_type == PyrexTypes.c_bint_type or
                 (arg_type.is_pyobject and arg_type.name == 'bool')):
             return self.arg.coerce_to_temp(env)
+        elif arg_type.is_string:
+            # Test for 0-length string with "ptr[0] != '\0'" instead of  "ptr != 0".
+            # This is safe because we know that we're otherwise coercing to Python 'bytes' / 'str',

comment_data.body:
The `IndexNode` in `char_ptr[:5]` always creates a Python object directly (without coercion node), that's why it doesn't hit the `is_string` branch. I don't think it could ever get optimised away because it requires the length, and we're not considering bounded C arrays here, only 0-terminated strings coming from a form of `char*`.

I think we could just generally include a `NULL` pointer check here, because why not? It's cheap and the C compiler will sometimes even optimise it away.

It seems reasonable to understand `bool(char_ptr)` as "does the pointer point to a non-empty string?", i.e. "does it point to a string" and "is the string non-empty". But that is something to apply generally, not just in this place. Sadly, `if char_ptr:` is already used for testing the pointer and does _not_ test the string. That leads to inconsistent semantics, depending on the specific usage of the pointer. `bool(char_ptr)` used to create a Python string copy for passing it into `bool()`, failing on `NULL` and testing the string length. It's just different from an if-test by accident.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -14643,6 +14663,21 @@ def coerce_to_boolean(self, env):
         if (arg_type == PyrexTypes.c_bint_type or
                 (arg_type.is_pyobject and arg_type.name == 'bool')):
             return self.arg.coerce_to_temp(env)
+        elif arg_type.is_string:
+            # Test for 0-length string with "ptr[0] != '\0'" instead of  "ptr != 0".
+            # This is safe because we know that we're otherwise coercing to Python 'bytes' / 'str',

commit.message:
Make "bool(c_int)" more efficient by avoiding to pass through a Python object.

Closes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/7015
Correctly exclude unicode strings from the implementation.
Fix and test string boolean coercion.
Generally implement "char_ptr" bool coercion as "char_ptr != NULL && char_ptr[0] != 0", testing for non-empty strings.

milestone.description: First feature release after the cleanup releases 3.0 and 3.1.

title: Make "bool(c_int)" more efficient by avoiding to pass through a Python object
